data.message: That really just sounds like, "be more specific."
It's more of a "in what measurable way is your purportedly novel invention novel?"
So you are requiring reduction to practice for all/most embodiments described?

Perhaps I am. Especially in my field, the vast majority of patents do not advance the art. Instead they protect an obvious aggregation of previous invention or a change of domain. For an example of the latter: Do "X" on a computer, or do "X" via the internet, where "X" is something like "sell clothing". The purpose of patenting is to advance the state of the art; the mechanism is to provide a limited-time monopoly. I think a lot of people skip to the mechanism, awarding inventors, and forget that there's supposed to be a novel advancement.

I should make a business patent which says that one can compose any transaction with "Do <transaction> on the internet/computer" to make a new patentable transaction.

I *said* it was crazy.

In much the same way, I think current copyright law has the cart before the horse. Copyright is there to advance culture, not to pay those who create. To the extent that we stifle new creation by maintaining monopolies on old creations ad infinitum-- regardless of how much money those rights make the holder-- we are working against its charter. It is demonstrably untrue that we need long copyright terms to foster creativity. (Ironically, Disney is a prime example. He created all the Disney classics with much much shorter terms.) One could make a case that long terms stagnates creativity, not just be reducing cultural reuse, but by removing incentives for existing rights-holders to create anything new. Instead, they work on leveraging and protecting their existing rights.

I appear to have ranted. Whoops.
(The only correlation between copyright and patents I meant to draw is the popular confusion of purpose with mechanism.)

I think you are making valid points.  In my industry  it is cost prohibitive to reduce all embodiments to practice, but the preferred embodiment usually is.  To your point,   I would agree it should be transparent how to assess infringement - may be easier for patents in my field by nature of the applications.

I think patents make sense for lots of things: medicine, mechanical innovations, etc. They don't make sense for software, period. They ought to be thrown out altogether for digital/process works, in my opinion, but I'd settle for a much shorter duration (5 years?). The only reason most companies even bother with patents is so that they can counter-sue when some lawyer at another big company decides to say you violated 400 of their 5000 patents that you couldn't have known existed.

Obviousness is already a patent hurdle.  I don't think it is always applied appropriately.  On some devices that I have been involved with, the inventors wanted to patent the algorithm of the software.  Unfortunately, since it would be so difficult to prove that a competitor used the exact algorithm in embedded software, that it makes little sense to try and protect it.

message: Crazy patent reform idea: A patent not only must teach the invention, but provide method(s) for determining infringement.
